item.description:
Hi all,
In 1943 while Germany controlled much of continental Europe and England was besieged by nightly air-raids, Laurence Olivier believed that an adaptation of Henry V might prove to be the propaganda film(!) the British most needed to inspire national pride. The result was one of the finest film interpretations of Shakespeare to date.

The AllMovie Guide states- "In contrast to previous Shakespeare adaptations, it was fresh and lively--even challenging and daring--in its presentation and structure; it had fun with its subject, while other versions had been reverent and respectful; and it delighted audiences, scholars, and critics alike"

Here is a complete review: http://www.reel.com/m...

The Brattle is also screening Olivier's version of Hamlet at 2:00 pm. I believe this is a separate admittance($) and would make for one long afternoon, although I might attend both.

As is the custom, I'll be holding a meetup sign near the front row after the movie and then we'll go to a local restaurant to discuss.

Hope you can make it,
Tom
item.name: Laurence Olivier Directs Shakespeare
